title: German chancellor called a ‘kraut’ by Leave.EU campaign group
text:
Leave.EU co-founder Arron Banks has apologised for the offensive poster attacking Angela Merkel (Picture: Getty / Twitter)

Leading Brexit group Leave.EU has apologised for a racist and offensive poster that insulted Angela Merkel.

The group released an attack on the German leader after remarks from Downing Street blaming her for the near collapse of Brexit talks.

They posted an image of Ms Merkel making something similar to a Nazi salute with the phrase ‘We didn’t win two World Wars to be pushed around by a Kraut.’

The poster received widespread condemnation from both Remain and Leave camps.

The poster followed a briefing by an unnamed source at Downing Street who tried to blame a breakdown in Brexit talks on Ms Merkel (Picture: Twitter)

Today Arron Banks, the co-founder of the Brexit group responsible for the poster, admitted: ‘The Leave.EU team went too far yesterday.’

The poster followed remarks yesterday by a Downing Street source who said a Brexit deal was ‘essentially impossible’ because of Ms Merkel’s demands.

Advertisement

The unnamed source claimed she had told Boris Johnson that Northern Ireland would need to stay within the EU’s customs union if he wanted a deal.

There has been no word from Ms Merkel about the Prime Minister’s recollection of their phone call conversation although political experts doubted that is what happened.

But European Council president Donald Tusk accused Mr Johnson of jeopardising the future security of the EU and the UK and indulging in a ‘silly blame game.’

The @LeaveEUOfficial team went too far yesterday but the real outrage is the German suggestion that Northern Ireland be separated from the UK. As a result we will delete the post and apologise accordingly…@piersmorgan on reflection the point could have been made better .. https://t.co/yaAGtnfQi6 — Arron Banks (@Arron_banks) October 9, 2019

The Leave.EU poster was released soon afterwards and quickly denounced as ‘racist’ and ‘offensive.’

The Twitter hashtag #WeheartGermany also rapidly began to trend with people supporting the country, its leader and its people.

In the House of Commons yesterday, MP Chris Leslie said: ‘Can I urge the minister to pause and reflect on the deliberate dog whistle briefing put out by No 10 against Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, in the phone call apparently as reported between herself and the PM, which of course has then sparked a series of frankly racist attacks against the Germans from Leave.EU and others.

‘This is an extremely dangerous course for the government to embark on.’

Michael Gove responded: ‘I take this opportunity to entirely disassociate myself from any racist or demeaning language against Germany.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘They are our friends, they are our allies, they are a great country.’

Boris Johnson has been accused of playing ‘silly games’ in his recollection of a phone call with German Chancellor Angela Merkel (Picture: AFP)

The Leave.EU campaign has now withdrawn the poster and spokesman Andy Wigmore said: ‘We went too far on this one and apologise unreservedly.

‘In these days of uncertainty and tribal anger over Brexit, perhaps we should all be a little less angry with our rhetoric on both sides.’

Mr Banks tweeted his apology, saying the group had gone too far with the image but used his social media post to again criticise Ms Merkel.

He said: ‘But the real outrage is the German suggestion that Northern Ireland be separated from the UK.’

One social media user told Mr Banks: ‘Any apology (I use that term loosely) is cancelled if there’s a “but” after it.’
description: Leading Brexit group Leave.EU has apologised for a racist and offensive poster that insulted Angela Merkel. The group released an attack on the German leader after remarks from Downing Street...
